awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FW-HTF: Augmented Cognition for Teaching: Transforming Teacher Work with Intelligent Cognitive Assistants
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim. 

K-12 STEM teachers are critical to the US economy. With investments in teaching quality representing enormous economic value, the quality of education has been identified as a significant determinant of gross domestic product economic growth. However, the US teacher workforce is experiencing a crisis: teacher demand exceeds supply at every level, and attrition is extraordinarily high for new teachers.  Further, while STEM teaching represents one of the areas of highest need, STEM teachers leave the profession at high rates. These developments call for innovative workforce augmentation technologies to improve K-12 STEM teachers' performance and quality of work-life. To address this critical national need, the project will investigate how intelligent cognitive assistants for teachers can transform teacher work to significantly increase teacher performance and teacher quality of work-life. The project centers on the design, development, and evaluation of the Intelligent Augmented Cognition for Teaching (I-ACT) framework for intelligent cognitive assistants for teachers. With a focus on assisting K-12 STEM teachers in technology-rich inquiry teaching that supports collaborative, problem-based STEM learning, I-ACT cognitive assistants provide teachers with (1) prospective pedagogical guidance (preparation support preceding classroom teaching), (2) concurrent pedagogical guidance (real-time support during classroom teaching), and (3) retrospective pedagogical guidance (reflection support within a community of practice following classroom teaching). The project will culminate with an experiment conducted with a fully implemented version of I-ACT in public middle schools in North Carolina and Indiana.

The project realizes its objective through two primary thrusts. First, the research team will design and develop I-ACT cognitive assistants for K-12 STEM teachers and test them in public school classrooms. Utilizing AI-based multimodal learning analytics and a social constructivist theory of pedagogy, I-ACT cognitive assistants use machine-learned models of teacher orchestration to provide guidance throughout the full teaching workflow. I-ACT cognitive assistants operate in a tight feedback loop in which collected data will drive successive iterations of machine learning to train refined teacher support models for improved I-ACT cognitive assistant functionalities. Second, the research team will investigate how I-ACT cognitive assistants improve K-12 STEM teacher performance and teacher quality of work-life. The team will conduct focus groups, case studies, semi-structured interviews, and observations of teachers using I-ACT cognitive assistants in school implementations with middle school science teachers at the project's partner schools. The team will also conduct quasi-experimental studies to determine I-ACT impact on teacher performance and quality of work-life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
K-12 STEM teachers are critical to the US economy. With investments in teaching quality representing enormous economic value, the quality of education has been identified as a significant determinant of economic growth in gross domestic product. However, the US teacher workforce is experiencing a crisis: teacher demand exceeds supply at every level, and attrition is extraordinarily high for new teachers. Further, while STEM teaching represents one of the areas of highest need, STEM teachers leave the profession at high rates. These developments call for innovative workforce augmentation technologies to improve K-12 STEM teachers' performance and quality of work-life. To address this critical national need, the project investigated how AI-driven cognitive assistants for teachers can transform teacher work to significantly increase teacher performance and teacher quality of work-life. The project centered on the design, development, and evaluation of the Intelligent Augmented Cognition for Teaching (I-ACT) framework for cognitive assistants for teachers, with a focus on assisting K-12 STEM teachers in technology-rich inquiry learning that supports collaborative, problem-based STEM learning. The project’s focus on collaborative co-design with teachers and integration of data-driven tools ensured that both teaching practices and student learning were enhanced. 


The project explored how the integration of the I-ACT Teacher Orchestration Assistant enhances K-12 problem-based learning by addressing the complex challenges of classroom orchestration and fostering scientific inquiry. Problem-based learning offers significant benefits for learning by fostering complex problem solving, critical reasoning, and collaborative inquiry. However, its inherently dynamic nature requires teachers to manage multiple groups, support collaborative interactions, and monitor learning trajectories, often creating a significant orchestration load. The Orchestration Assistant was developed to address these challenges by providing real-time data visualization, interaction insights, and facilitation tools. Teachers utilized the Orchestration Assistant to monitor group progress, guide discussions, track participation, and foster collaboration, enabling more effective facilitation of multi-level classroom activities. By integrating these features, the Orchestration Assistant bridged the gap between instructional goals and real-time classroom needs, supporting students in developing critical thinking and problem-solving skills. The results emphasized how orchestration tools reduce cognitive demands on teachers while supporting their ability to manage complex classroom dynamics. By using the Orchestration Assistant, teachers were able to scaffold disciplinary learning, encourage collaboration, and promote deeper engagement in inquiry-based tasks. This research addressed a key gap in understanding how teacher-facing orchestration technologies reshape classroom dynamics and improve problem-based learning outcomes. It provided valuable insights into the design of professional development programs and technology-enhanced learning tools that align with diverse classroom contexts and pedagogical approaches.


The I-ACT project serves as a model for leveraging AI to transform collaborative inquiry learning in classrooms by providing tools and strategies that improve educational outcomes. It demonstrates the potentially transformative impact of cognitive assistants that equip teachers with real-time data, actionable insights, and adaptive scaffolding, enabling teachers to focus on supporting the multifaceted nature of student learning. Cognitive tools for teachers such as the I-ACT cognitive assistant allow educators to focus on supporting student engagement, collaboration, and inquiry-based exploration rather than being overwhelmed by the logistics of classroom management. Teachers report greater confidence and efficiency in their instructional practices as a result of the professional development and co-design activities. The I-ACT Orchestration Assistant’s real-time monitoring features, such as tracking student progress, participation, and scientific discussions, empower teachers to make informed, immediate instructional decisions. For example, customizable alerts help teachers identify and address situations requiring intervention, while actionable insights from the Orchestration Assistant allow educators to scaffold student learning in ways that foster equitable participation and deeper engagement with STEM content. These advances streamline and support instructional workflows for teachers and reduce orchestration load during classroom interactions. Students benefit from tailored teacher interventions and scaffolding, which support their ability to engage meaningfully in group work and build essential skills in communication, critical thinking, and scientific reasoning. Additionally, the system’s engagement detection model enables teachers to stay updated on the changing engagement levels of students as they work on problem-solving tasks, even while assisting other students. This ensures that no group is overlooked, enabling teachers to identify and address potential disengagement or struggles in real time, thereby fostering a more supportive and productive learning environment. By providing real-time insights into learning, these cognitive assistants can enhance teachers’ confidence and satisfaction with their ability to meet the diverse needs of their students effectively. Thus, cognitive assistants for teachers can reshape educational experiences by bridging the gap between innovative technologies and classroom realities.
